posts.cooked: Here for advice. We want to get our shooter to a certain rpm, hopefully quickly. What are your suggestions in terms of control. Right now we have a PIDF or more specifically just P and F to control the shooter. Its not tested but is this strategy a viable approach using the WPILib PID and Feedforward classes for a shooter? Or is a bang-bang controller a good idea or simply have set output to the motor controller and calling it a day? Thanks so much

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Bang bang is easy, PF (controlling motor voltage, not duty cycle percent) is optimal.

The main limitation of both strategies is the delay in the sensor used to detect the speed and change the output. Larger delays will either increase the steady-state oscillation of a bang-bang controller, or reduce the maximum P gain you can use without overshooting or ringing.

I don’t think anything you’ve described won’t work, though.
So considering comp is tomorrow, I should do Bang Bang because it is easier to do within the time constraints?

posts.name: Rick Lance
posts.cooked: What motor/motor controller are you using?  Can you give more info on your setup?
We are using NEOs and SparkMaxes. It is a flywheel shooter

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Well, if you have something functional now, I’d recommend being very careful about changing anything. Closed loop control is not necessarily “better” in all cases for shooter wheels. Be sure, through backups or git or just good ole caution, you can undo whatever changes you’re attempting now.

From there, perhaps, start with bang-bang:
If you are already familiar with implementing PF, I would go with that. The only number you’ll have to tune is P

gerthworm:

Closed loop control is not necessarily “better” in all cases for shooter wheels.

Elaborate?

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
FRC6302:

The only number you’ll have to tune is P

Not necessarily. F also has to overcome friction in the system. If this is not known yet, it’ll be bigger than the theoretical motor Feed-forward gain.

FRC6302:

Elaborate?

How much energy you dump into the ball while it’s in contact with the shooter wheel can impact trajectory. It could also change dynamics of how the wheels, ball, and backplane interact in terms of slip and spin. It’s usually small, but I have to hedge with OP, since I know little about their shooter setup.

I don’t know for certain that there’s some system interaction where moving to closed loop control over … whatever OP currently has… will necessarily improve on-field performance. I wouldn’t recommend OP assume that either.

I’m also attempting to discourage pursuit of closed-loop purely for the desire to improve. At this hour, if they have something functional, I’d suggest time is better spent on things like driver practice, match review, or sleeping.

posts.name: Rick Lance
posts.cooked: You might check out these examples and at some point implement PID.   Maybe get Bang Bang ready first just to get something going and work towards the PID. https://docs.revrobotics.com/sparkmax/software-resources/spark-max-code-examples

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: Class should be basically the same, though I can’t say I’ve used it.
